-Ns-6LBD9O_38-C0I07w.title: Tag
-Ns-6LBD9O_38-C0I07w.definition: Definition: Tags are the basic building blocks of HTML. They are used to define elements within a web document and provide structure to the content. Tags are enclosed in angle brackets < > and typically come in pairs, with an opening tag indicating the beginning of an element and a closing tag indicating the end.

-Ns-6LBEUUkkoGc8xwy8.title: Attribute
-Ns-6LBEUUkkoGc8xwy8.definition: Attributes provide additional information about HTML elements and are used to modify the behavior or appearance of an element. Attributes are added to the opening tag of an element and consist of a name and a value separated by an equal sign =. Examples of attributes include src, href, and class.

-Ns-6LBFhfATTuJzJpCa.title: Element
-Ns-6LBFhfATTuJzJpCa.definition: An element is a structural component of an HTML document, defined by a pair of tags enclosing content. Each element consists of an opening tag, content, and a closing tag. Elements can be nested within one another to create hierarchical structures.

-Ns-6LBHMUSTGeRjHoEX.title: DOCTYPE Declaration
-Ns-6LBHMUSTGeRjHoEX.definition: The DOCTYPE declaration is an instruction at the beginning of an HTML document that specifies the version of HTML being used and provides instructions to the web browser on how to render the document. It helps ensure that the document is parsed and displayed correctly by web browsers.

-Ns-6LBI25XKsSIJy8MO.title: Semantic HTML
-Ns-6LBI25XKsSIJy8MO.definition: Semantic HTML refers to the use of HTML markup to convey the meaning and structure of content on a web page, rather than just its appearance. Semantic elements such as <header>, <footer>, <article>, and <nav> provide context and clarity to the content, making it more accessible to both users and search engines. Semantic HTML helps improve the organization, accessibility, and search engine optimization (SEO) of web pages.

-Ns-6LBJmcc5i9DmCXi8.title: Selector
-Ns-6LBJmcc5i9DmCXi8.definition: Selectors are patterns used to target HTML elements on which styles are applied. They define which elements in the document tree will be affected by the rules specified in the CSS stylesheet. Selectors can target elements based on their type, class, ID, attributes, or relationship to other elements.

-Ns-6LBKQwP8-Dsp3zOH.title: Property
-Ns-6LBKQwP8-Dsp3zOH.definition: Properties are the specific visual characteristics or behaviors that can be applied to HTML elements using CSS. Each property has a name and a value, which defines how the element should be styled. Examples of CSS properties include color, font-size, margin, padding, and background.

-Ns-6LBLMFUJ0C_EVmj5.title: Declaration
-Ns-6LBLMFUJ0C_EVmj5.definition: In CSS, a declaration consists of a property and its corresponding value, enclosed within curly braces { }. Declarations are used to specify the styling rules that apply to a particular selector. Multiple declarations can be grouped together within a CSS rule to define the complete set of styles for a given selector.

-Ns-6LBMc2ZiU1msOUR7.title: Class
-Ns-6LBMc2ZiU1msOUR7.definition: Classes are a way to apply a specific set of styles to one or more HTML elements. A class is defined in CSS using a period (.) followed by the class name. Elements with the same class attribute value can be styled consistently by referencing the class name in CSS rules.

-Ns-6LBNHoGe20BHCepf.title: Pseudo-class
-Ns-6LBNHoGe20BHCepf.definition: Pseudo-classes are keywords added to selectors that specify a special state or behavior of an element that cannot be targeted using ordinary classes or IDs. Pseudo-classes allow for styling elements based on user interaction (e.g., :hover, :active), element states (e.g., :checked, :focus), or position within a document (e.g., :first-child, :last-child).

-Ns-6LBPqkMz_t-CUrt5.title: Variable
-Ns-6LBPqkMz_t-CUrt5.definition: A variable in JavaScript is a symbolic name that represents a value. Variables are used to store and manipulate data within a program. In JavaScript, variables can hold various types of data, including numbers, strings, arrays, objects, and functions. They are declared using keywords such as var, let, or const.

-Ns-6LBQ9DO5tVuylhYC.title: Function
-Ns-6LBQ9DO5tVuylhYC.definition: A function in JavaScript is a block of reusable code that performs a specific task or calculates a value. Functions encapsulate a set of instructions and can accept inputs, called parameters, and return a result. Functions are essential for organizing code, promoting reusability, and improving readability.

-Ns-6LBR1n-SCscqo5A0.title: Conditional Statement
-Ns-6LBR1n-SCscqo5A0.definition: Conditional statements in JavaScript are used to execute different code blocks based on specified conditions. The most common conditional statement is the if statement, which allows developers to test a condition and execute a block of code if the condition is true. JavaScript also supports else if and else clauses for handling multiple conditions.

-Ns-6LBSo0rrnwTPeUbr.title: Loop
-Ns-6LBSo0rrnwTPeUbr.definition: A loop in JavaScript is a programming construct that repeats a block of code multiple times until a specified condition is met. JavaScript provides several types of loops, including for, while, and do-while loops, each with its own syntax and use cases. Loops are commonly used for iterating over arrays, processing lists of data, or performing repetitive tasks.

-Ns-6LBT5km3cZfQsPjC.title: DOM (Document Object Model)
-Ns-6LBT5km3cZfQsPjC.definition: The Document Object Model (DOM) is a programming interface for web documents that represents the structure of an HTML or XML document as a tree of objects. In JavaScript, the DOM provides a way to access and manipulate elements and their attributes within a web page dynamically. Developers can use DOM methods and properties to interact with the content, structure, and style of a document programmatically.
